etymologies: early 19th century; earliest use found in Precept & Example. From bio- + -graph, after biographic, biography

definitions: A biography or biographical article; especially a short profile of a public figure.
An early form of motion-picture camera and projector combined. Compare "bioscope".

notes.text: The name of the American Mutoscope Company, founded in 1895 by W. K. L. Dickson, was changed to the American Mutoscope and Biograph Company in 1899, and to the Biograph Company in 1909. Most later uses of the word biograph are references to the company.

etymologies: late 18th century. Back-formation from either biographer or biography

definitions: To write a biography or biographical profile of (a person, especially a historical or public figure); (also) to record (historical information) in a biographical account. Occasionally without object.
